bibl.title: Letter from Robert Carter to James Bradley, June 25, 1729

div1.p: Robert Carter writes to London merchant James Bradley, June 25, 1729, to send a bill of lading (not present) and to report a shipment of tobacco on another ship. He hopes to learn soon that Parliament has repealed the act prohibiting the importation of stemmed tobacco into Britain. He encloses an invoice (not present) for goods.

div1.head: Letter from Robert Carter to James Bradley, June 25, 1729

opener.dateline:
Rappahannock, [Lancaster County, Virginia]
June 25th. 1729
Mr. Jas: Bradley

div1.p:
This Accompanys your Ship the Welcome Capt. Trice
and brings you a bill of Lading for 32 hogsheads on board the said Ship they are all
of my own Crops and I hope will rise so Well as to procurate a good Sale. You
have 10 Hogsheads more in the Forward Capt. Lonney.

The Wms.Burgh hath bin long Expected and wee hope will
bring us Some good news at last. And Accots. of our last Years Crops that may
Enable us to lively our Labours, The General report in the county now is that
the repealing the Clause in the Act. of Palli. prohibiting the Stemming of Tobbo: wd.
Infallibly be Carried if this prove true I must be be of Opinion it will very
much help us. Wee must wait with Expectation what will be our fate in this
respect. I have many a time in my Day Seen Tobbo: at as low an Ebb as it is now
and still Providence hath by one means or othey taken care to releive us.

I have herein sent to you an Invoice for Some goods—
Desiring your utmost care in the well buying and Safe Packing of them If
[y]ou continue the Welcome a Ship for our river I had as live have them by Trice
as by any body, he Appears to be a Carefull obliging person in his business it is too
large a great deal for our Income but wee must be Supplyed with necessaryes
for our familyes and for the Carrying on our business. Altho [. .. .]
[. . .] former [. . .] Necessity is an Arm'd man and the Calls of nature
will recur, in spite of our Teeths I shall wish your ship safe to you & Conclude
at present
div1.closer:
Sir
Yor. most humble Servt.
per Trice

div1.head: NOTES
div1.note: Source copy consulted: Letter book, 1728 August-1731 July, Robert Carter Papers (acc. no. 3807), Albert and Shirley Small Special Collections Library, University of Virginia.

Robert Carter generally used a return address of "Rappahannock" for the river on which he lived rather than "Corotoman," the name of his home, on his correspondence, especially to merchants abroad. The county and colony have been added for clarity.

[1] James Bradley was a London merchant with whom Carter dealt from at least 1723 until his death. As noted in his letter to Bradley of 1727 May 17, Bradley owned the Welcome, but little information about Bradley has been located.

[2] The 140 ton Welcome was owned by London merchant James Bradley to whom Carter would write about her on 1727 May 17. John Trice (Frice) was her captain, 1723-1729. (Survey Report 6801 summarizing Adm 68/195, 154r, found in the microfilms of the Virginia Colonial Records Project, Albert and Shirley Small Special Collections Library, University of Virginia.)

[3] The Forward was a London ship of 150-200 tons commanded in 1728-29 by William Loney, and in 1731 by George Buckridge. (Survey Report 6800 summarizing Adm. 68/194 and Survey Report 6801 summarizing Adm 68/195, Virginia Colonial Records Project, Albert and Shirley Small Special Collections Library, University of Virginia. )

[4] Isham Randolph was captain of the London ship Williamsburgh in 1725-26, and Charles Rogers commanded her in 1727-28. (Admiralty 68/194, ff. 39v, found in the microfilms of the Virginia Colonial Records Project, Albert and Shirley Small Special Collections Library, University of Virginia.)

[5] Parliament had passed an act forbidding the importation of stemmed tobacco in 1722. John Randolph was sent to England in 1729 as agent for Virginia to try to have the act overturned; his mission would be successful. (Arthur Pierce Middleton. Tobacco Coast: A Maritime History of the Chesapeake Bay in the Colonial Era. [Newport News, VA: Mariners' Museum, 1953.] p. 116.)
